subject: Add pattern write and verify to erase
commitMessage:
Add pattern write and verify to erase

The goals are to write a non-compressible and verifiable pattern to the
drive as a means to validate that the drive is working, and ensure all
blocks have been overwritten.

Tested:
$ systemctl stop emmc.service
$ ./eStoraged  -b /dev/mmcblk0&
$busctl call xyz.openbmc_project.eStoraged.mmcblk0 /xyz/openbmc_project/storage/mmcblk0 xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume Erase s xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume.EraseMethod.LogicalOverWrite --timeout=1200

$busctl call xyz.openbmc_project.eStoraged.mmcblk0 /xyz/openbmc_project/storage/mmcblk0 xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume Erase s xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume.EraseMethod.LogicalVerify --timeout=1200

$echo "jebr" > /dev/mmcblk0

$busctl call xyz.openbmc_project.eStoraged.mmcblk0 /xyz/openbmc_project/storage/mmcblk0 xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume Erase s xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume.EraseMethod.LogicalVerify --timeout=1200
Call failed: The operation failed internally.

Change-Id: Ibc1254279b1f46246eb37056ea6e4e1a57159bb9
Signed-off-by: John Edward Broadbent <jebr@google.com>

I think you're supposed to say "Add pattern...", right?
Yes, the imperative mood or whatnot that we prefer for commit header = "Add pattern"
too many characters on one line?

added

Note, when testing the original version it took 29 hours to write the pattern. So I changed the write and read to buffer a 4k block.

Thanks for taking a look at this.
Let me know what you think
Does this return value serve a purpose? Maybe writePattern and verifyPattern should be void?
should we just match the types of rand and driveSize, which this variable is interacting with - and go with uint64_t?
yep fixed. it actually caused an issue when I was testing it. 2GB is the largest value that 32 bits can represent.

You can achieve this with
```
std::equal(span1.begin(), span1.end(), span2.begin(), span2.end());
```
Hmm, I'm not sure what the best practices is for defining the SEED (as in, should it be a static constepxr in the cpp?) - is it ok that this is always static? Where did this come from?

> is it ok that this is always static?
Yes, the prng will give different values if it is not the same in write and verify. That would prevent the sequence from being validated. Also I did not manual test with the generated sequence to ensure entropy for the static seed. I did not see any benefit to a random seed.

> Should it be a static constepxr in the cpp?
That would also be a valid way to set this up. It does not need to be compile time evaluated so I had it as a define.

> Where did this come from?
ascii(jebr) => 6a 65 62 72

nit: Just to revive this and the new define that we have for BLOCK_SIZE, I guess here's the Google styling guide that prefers we don't use preprocessor macro for definition: https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Preprocessor_Macros

In the internal copy of totw/140 we can see "Discouraged Alternatives" that define just a constant this way.

Obviously we are following the OpenBMC standard here so we don't have to follow  the Google standard, but I think it'd probably be good to follow the Google standard as a backup
I think this would fail once we rebase to using the general errors
Should we add test coverage for writePattern failing too?

I had trouble coming up with a good test for just the write.
If I pass a fault fd, I get a system error, handled by sdbusplus.
Let me know if you had anything specific in mind.
Hmm I guess we can't mock out fd here? If not, yeah I'm not sure if we can do much.
yeah, the writePattern get tested in all the first 2 cases against the readPattern.
Maybe we should add an EXPECT_NO_THROW?

the test is almost the same but the size is different (4097 and not 4096)

because the disk size is not a divisible by the read/write size, extra logic is verified by this test.

Ah! missed that. I think it'd be good to point it out a little more expectedly just for readability. Maybe just a comment above the size definition to say that 4097 is not divisible or naming it badSize instead of size so it's a little more obvious
I had to refactor it to buffer a 4k block of the sequence.

Hmm, I don't believe we want to be using new here without some kind of RAII to automatically delete this when exiting (although I see you covered the places where we exit - if we add any exits in the future, we may forget to).

I guess, do we NEED std::byte here? if we do, can we use std::make_unique instead for a unique pointer instead?

make sense, I was worried about performance and looking to get ride of implicit cast. So I used simple data types. 
But I switched to vectors

std::bytes are used because stdplus uses it.
https://github.com/openbmc/stdplus/blob/master/src/stdplus/fd/impl.hpp#L14
If this is a known size and will the size will remain the same - I think std::array is preferred.
I believe reinterpret_cast is preferred over () style casting
nit: Since we're using this a few times, should we just declare this as a constexpr for readability
I think this is the final nit - sorry for the back and forth! I probably should have dug in further when we were addressing that comment

So sorry for another nit, we should have these lower cased.

I swear this is the last one and we should be home free
